Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The MOSFIRE Deep Evolution Field Survey
Award.AbstractNarration: To study galaxies during the cosmic era of maximum star formation and supermassive black hole growth requires observing them at great distances, corresponding to cosmological redshifts between 1.5 and 3.0. The visible light emitted by these galaxies carries information about their stellar and gaseous contents; owing to the redshift, this light is observed at infrared wavelengths. The new, NSF-funded, Multi-Object Spectrometer for Infra-Red Exploration (MOSFIRE) on the Keck I telescope represents a major development for the study of these galaxies, offering increases in sensitivity and survey efficiency by factors of approximately 5 and 100, respectively. This project, the MOSFIRE Deep Evolution Field (MOSDEF) Survey, will chart the evolution of the rest-frame optical spectra for approximately 2000 galaxies between 1.5 and 3.5, more than an order of magnitude improvement over existing surveys. The project will make use of 44 nights allocated on the Keck I telescope through 2016, and will survey three well-studied regions of the sky already having extensive multi-wavelength datasets. By combining new and existing data, the proposing team will characterize the star formation and accreting black hole activity in distant galaxies, their masses, contents and structures, and the manner in which baryonic matter passes through them. In collaboration with theorists, the MOSDEF team will use these results to test and inform forefront models of galaxy evolution. The MOSDEF spectra will be publicly released to the astronomical community to enable additional investigations. Graduate and undergraduate students will be supported by the project and involved in the research, and team members will develop pedagogical resources for K-12 teachers on the key aspects of the science and techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rest-frame optical spectroscopy provides basic insight into the stellar, gas, dust, and black hole contents of galaxies.  The MOSFIRE Deep Evolution Field (MOSDEF) survey is an ambitious project in which we have assembled the first true statistical sample of moderate-resolution rest-frame optical spectra for ~1500 galaxies at "cosmic high noon." With the MOSDEF survey, we target galaxies in three distinct intervals spanning from 9 to 12 billion years ago in lookback time.  This range in cosmic time includes the peak of both star-formation and supermassive black hole accretion activity, when the patterns that we see in today's galaxy population were still being set. As such, this is a critical epoch for understanding the assembly of galaxies and the growth of black holes.

Our team was awarded 48.5 Keck nights from 2012-2016 by the University of California Keck Time Allocation Committee to conduct observations with the Keck/MOSFIRE spectrograph in three extragalactic legacy fields with extensive multi-wavelength datasets spanning from the radio to X-ray regimes, including high-resolution Hubble Space Telescope imaging. The existing multi-wavelength data provide a comprehensive picture of each target for which we obtain rest-optical spectroscopy.

We recently completed Keck/MOSFIRE observations for the MOSDEF survey, and have already produced a wealth of published science results. Our results provide unprecedented insights into the fundamental properties of distant galaxies: the rates at which they form stars, and how star-formation rate relates to galaxy mass; the nature of dust emission and absorption; heavy element enrichment and physical properties of the interstellar medium; dynamical properties and masses; stellar chemical abundances patters and galaxy assembly histories; and the demographics of active black hole growth.  Measurements of these key galaxy properties at early cosmic times both constrain and inform forefront models of galaxy formation and evolution. Thus far, we have provided three public releases of MOSDEF spectroscopic redshifts to the astronomy community, in order to facilitate the investigations of other groups. We will also provide a public release of spectra and associated measurements for the full MOSDEF dataset.

The MOSDEF survey has provided extensive opportunities for training and mentoring students. There are currently nine graduate students actively involved in many different aspects of the project (six of whom are women), and they have gained hands-on experience in observing at the Keck observatory, reducing and analyzing spectroscopic data, and leading the majority of the science publications to come out of the MOSDEF team. Overall, the MOSDEF program has supported the PhD research of nine University of California graduate students, and also the summer research of two undergraduate students. The MOSDEF team maintains a public website that describes the team and the survey, provides links to public MOSDEF data releases for other astronomers, and features pedagogical materials produced by the MOSDEF team explaining MOSDEF science to non-experts.
